titlestmt.titleproper:
School of Education, Health, Nursing, and Art Professions, Department of Art and Art Professions Dissertations
1940-1995
RG 26.0
titlestmt.author: Finding aid prepared by Finding Aid prepared by Lisa Darms

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using the Archivists' Toolkit 2012-02-16T11:11-0500

did.unittitle: Records of the School of Education, Health, Nursing, and Art Professions (SEHNAP), Department of Art and Art Professions Dissertations
did.abstract: Dissertations and theses for the Art Department of the School of Education. The thesis topics vary widely in subject and time period.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The theses remain in their original order.
The files are grouped into one series.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: In the 1940's, PhD candidates in the department of Art Education spent at least one year working on what was then referred to as a thesis. By the 1990's, students in Art and Arts Professions produced dissertations as part of their PhD requirements. This collection contains dissertations and theses on a broad range of topics pertaining to art history, education and theory across diverse geographical and historical categories. Many of the theses/dissertations are bound, and some are in multiple volumes.

bioghist.head: Historical/Biographical Note
bioghist.p: The Department of Art and Art Professions is part of the New York University School of Education, which is currently called the Steinhardt School of Culture, Education, and Human Development. The School was founded in 1890 as the School of Pedagogy, renamed the School of Education in 1921, and was called the School of Education, Health, Nursing, and Arts Professions (SEHNAP) from 1974 to 1994.

At the beginning of the period represented by this collection, the School of Education's Art courses were taught within Art Education, a program that focused on the training of teachers, supervisors, and directors of art education in elementary and secondary schools. By the 1990's, the renamed Department of Art and Art Professions had expanded to offer majors in Studio Art, Arts Education, Art Therapy, and Arts Administration, offering a PhD in Arts and Humanities or Art Education. The current focus of the program is interdisciplinary, providing theoretical and historical training in visual culture to support art administrators, educators, and scholars.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Published citations should take the following form:Identification of item, date (if known); The School of Education, Health, Nursing, and Art Professions, Art Department Dissertations; RG 26.0; box number; folder number; New York University Archives, New York University

userestrict.head: Use Restrictions
userestrict.p:
Some materials may be restricted. Permission to publish materials must be obtained in writing from the:
New York University Archives
Elmer Holmes Bobst Library
70 Washington Square South
New York, NY 10012
Phone: (212) 998-2641
Fax: (212) 995-4225
E-mail: university.archives@library.nyu.edu

accessrestrict.head: Access Restrictions
accessrestrict.p: Institutional records of New York University are closed for a period of 20 years from the date of their creation (the date on which each document was written). Board of Trustees records are similarly closed for 35 years from the date of creation. The opening date for files spanning several years will be 20 years from the most recent date. Access will be given to material already 20 years old contained within a collection that is not yet open when such material can be isolated from the rest of the collection.

Materials related to personnel, faculty grievances, job searches and all files with information that falls under the University's Family Educational Rights and Privacy Act (FERPA) policy are permanently restricted.

Material pertaining to individual student records may be restricted in accordance with the Family Educational Rights and Privacy Act (FERPA). Please contact the Archives with specific questions regarding access to such records.

This collection is in
off-site storage .

custodhist.head: Provenance
custodhist.p: The Art and Arts Professions dissertations were transferred to the New York University Archives by the Department of Art and Arts Professions in 1997.
